body:
Versions:

* Cython ``0.29`` branch: commit [c0dfb9c2f592b7e0ece90ec83fbadcf6e6da3d47](https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/c0dfb9c2f592b7e0ece90ec83fbadcf6e6da3d47) (May 17, 2022)
* Python 3.11.0b3+: commit [a848a9894d](https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/a848a9894d2b23386512df875a29c0ff6353e78f) (Jun  6 2022)


Reproducer, ``myext.pyx``:

```
# cython: language_level=3
cdef extern from "Python.h":
    ctypedef class types.CodeType [object PyCodeObject]:
        pass
```

Build the extension (I make the assumption that ``cythonize`` uses Python 3.11):

```
cythonize -i myext.pyx
```

Importing the C extension fails:

```
$ python3.11 -c 'import myext'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "myext.pyx", line 1, in init myext
    # cython: language_level=3
                               
ValueError: types.CodeType size changed, may indicate binary incompatibility. Expected 168 from C header, got 160 from PyObject
```

To get Python 3.11 with Cython, you can use for example:

```
wget https://www.python.org/ftp/python/3.11.0/Python-3.11.0b3.tar.xz
tar -xf Python-3.11.0b3.tar.xz
cd Python-3.11.0b3
./configure --prefix /opt/py311
make
make install
cd ..
/opt/py311/bin/python3.11 -m pip install Cython
```

Then use ``/opt/py311/bin/cythonize``. You can use a different prefix.

---

The problem is that ``tp_basicsize`` of ``&PyCode_Type`` is 160 bytes, whereas and ``sizeof(PyCodeObject)`` is 168 bytes.

---

Issue discovered when on my PR to update gevent to Python 3.11: https://github.com/gevent/gevent/pull/1872#issuecomment-1146149244

@hroncok proposed a Cython pull request in Fedora: https://src.fedoraproject.org/rpms/Cython/pull-request/35

I am working on reworking @hroncok's PR to propose a PR to the master branch of Cython.

cc @encukou who helped to debug this tedious issue.

comment_data.body:
``tp_basicsize`` of ``&PyCode_Type`` was changed in Python 3.11 by the commit https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/2bde6827ea4f136297b2d882480b981ff26262b6 by @brandtbucher:

```
 PyTypeObject PyCode_Type = {
     PyVarObject_HEAD_INIT(&PyType_Type, 0)
     "code",
-    sizeof(PyCodeObject),
-    0,
+    offsetof(PyCodeObject, co_code_adaptive),
+    sizeof(_Py_CODEUNIT),
     (destructor)code_dealloc,           /* tp_dealloc */
     0,                                  /* tp_vectorcall_offset */
     0,                                  /* tp_getattr */
```

A couple of thoughts (not based on an in-depth look):

* Try `cythonize -if myext.pyx` to force recompilation. I've definitely seen similar errors go away with recompilation.
* I'm not sure if you can use variable size classes with as cdef classes - you certainly can't inherit from then. It may be that this change just means that you can't use CodeType as a cdef extern class

> I'm not sure if you can use variable size classes with as cdef classes - you certainly can't inherit from then. It may be that this change just means that you can't use CodeType as a cdef extern class

The reproducer was extracted from gevent Cython code which works well on Python 3.10:

https://github.com/gevent/gevent/blob/5858d226045f701deb8e4b49c03db4cab63053d6/src/gevent/_gevent_cgreenlet.pxd#L55-L58

The code fails on Python 3.11 which changed how ``PyCode_Type.tp_basicsize`` is defined.
I created the following issue in the Python bug tracker: https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/93585
In `bytes` , the extra item is for the terminating NUL, which isn't part of `tp_size`.

It sounds broadly like there might be two acceptable (and widely used) sizes for the struct of a variably sized PyObject: 
1. `tp_basicsize` and
2.  `tp_basicsize+tp_itemsize`

In that was we should probably accept either?

The size check is mainly a sanity check anyway so we can probably afford to be a bit lenient in this case (at the cost of a few false negatives).

The patch to Fedora looks like a good starting point (it isn't quite what I'm proposing, but it looks fairly close)

The other thing is that there is a `check_size` keyword for extern extension types (https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/extension_types.html#name-specification-clause)

That doesn't help you here because even `ignore` only allows the struct to be smaller, not larger. But we could always add more options (to be used at the user's own risk)

In *this particular* case, `tp_basicsize+tp_itemsize` won't work because `PyCodeObject`'s itemsize is `sizeof(_Py_CODEUNIT)` while the struct has `char[]`. I'm not sure why exactly, but it's probably a rare edge case. In most cases, allowing `tp_basicsize+tp_itemsize` should work.

Another option that comes to mind is adding a directive that would make Cython use `offsetof(object_struct_name, items_member)` instead of `sizeof`.

An option to disable the check entirely, or to allow smaller structs, would probably help in dealing with future edge cases.

Actually, it looks like gevent code can be simplified to:
```cython
cdef extern from "Python.h":
    ctypedef class types.CodeType [object PyCodeObject]:
        pass
    ctypedef class types.FrameType [object PyFrameObject]:
        pass

    CodeType PyFrame_GetCode(FrameType frame)
```
i.e. nothing is actually needed from the structs, but the C API deals with `PyCodeObject*` and `PyFrameObject*`.
In the future, the structs might even become opaque (just `typedef struct PyCodeObject PyCodeObject;`), so `sizeof()` will stop working.
I don't know if Cython has a way to deal with classes backed by an opaque struct?

> I don't know if Cython has a way to deal with classes backed by an opaque struct?

Just pass an untyped object? If Cython doesn't need to know or care about direct access to any of the members then there's no value in using a cdef class

That gives compiler warnings when passing it to `PyCodeObject *PyFrame_GetCode(PyFrameObject *frame)`, but I guess those can be removed with casts.

Thank you for your help! This issue no longer blocks our effort to get gevent working with 3.11, though the itemsize/basicsize check could still be improved.

> In _this particular_ case, `tp_basicsize+tp_itemsize` won't work because `PyCodeObject`'s itemsize is `sizeof(_Py_CODEUNIT)` while the struct has `char[]`. I'm not sure why exactly, but it's probably a rare edge case. In most cases, allowing `tp_basicsize+tp_itemsize` should work.

That suggests to me that the check is "between `tp_basicsize` and `tp_basicsize+tp_itemsize` (inclusive)".
 
> Another option that comes to mind is adding a directive that would make Cython use `offsetof(object_struct_name, items_member)` instead of `sizeof`.

My feeling is that this would be a bit complex to express.

> An option to disable the check entirely, or to allow smaller structs, would probably help in dealing with future edge cases.

That's probably the way to go. I think we've resisted it because we can foresee endless bug reports of "I got this error message, so I disabled the check, and now my program is crashing for some reason". But there are clearly cases where the check isn't suitable and causes problems.

> > An option to disable the check entirely, or to allow smaller structs, would probably help in dealing with future edge cases.
> 
> That's probably the way to go. I think we've resisted it because we can foresee endless bug reports of "I got this error message, so I disabled the check, and now my program is crashing for some reason". But there are clearly cases where the check isn't suitable and causes problems.

Let's wait for feedback on the new size checks from #4869. Adding an option always means admitting defeat regarding a proper solution. In the end, this is a safety check meant to produce error messages instead of crashes. That's what it still does, I think, especially with a strict size check in the case of struct inheritance.

So, allowing any size for `sizeof(PyCodeObject)` that is between `tp_basicsize` and `tp_basicsize + tp_itemsize` still fails in Py3.11, message being `Expected 192 from C header, got 186 from PyObject`. Note how `sizeof(PyCodeObject)` is 6 bytes larger than even `tp_basicsize + tp_itemsize` (GHA CI, 64 bit Linux). I wonder how that's possible.

The new struct ends with this (SIZE == 1):
```
    char *_co_linearray;          /* array of line offsets */                  \
    int _co_firsttraceable;       /* index of first traceable instruction */   \
    /* Scratch space for extra data relating to the code object.               \
       Type is a void* to keep the format private in codeobject.c to force     \
       people to go through the proper APIs. */                                \
    void *co_extra;                                                            \
    char co_code_adaptive[(SIZE)];                                             \
```
So, there's an `int` between two pointers, which probably induces some alignment space, but then I wonder if `sizeof()` also adds padding after the last struct field? One code unit has size 2, so 2 item bytes where the aligned struct expected 8 would explain the difference of 6.

@vstinner @encukou Do you think that's what happens here?

> I wonder if `sizeof()` also adds padding after the last struct field?

Yes, it does :(
It seems that the upper bound should be rounded up to the nearest `alignof(the struct)` boundary. (But `alignof` is C11. For older C... well, people tend to get away with using `sizeof(long long)` as maximum alignment, or even hardcoding it to 64  even on platforms where `long long` has 128-byte alignment, since `long long` is rare in complex structs.)


> Adding an option always means admitting defeat regarding a proper solution. In the end, this is a safety check meant to produce error messages instead of crashes.

It's good to know there is possibility to admit defeat :)
This has been resolved by weakening the conditions in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4894

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3str`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: [BUG] Using types.CodeType in Python 3.11 fails with ValueError: types.CodeType size changed, may indicate binary incompatibility. Expected 168 from C header, got 160 from PyObject
